Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Software tool to assist mental health care providers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project will be to leverage advanced computational and machine learning technology to assist psychiatric hospitals in stratifying patients' readmission risk, optimization of post-discharge interventions and promotion of wellness. Healthcare reforms in the United States have emphasized provision of value-based healthcare services as opposed to the traditional 'fee-for-service' approach. A major outcome to be used by regulatory bodies and payers is patient readmission - interpreted as a proxy measure of quality of care provided during hospitalization. Therefore, psychiatric facilities will increasingly be required to pay special attention to patients with a high likelihood of readmission after discharge. This will be a significant departure from the traditional approach and require novel analytical tools able to proactively guide interventions. Computational and machine learning technologies can assist healthcare providers in stratifying patients' readmission risks, optimize post-discharge interventions and resource allocation - translating into better patient outcomes.

This I-Corps project is focused on exploring a commercialization opportunity for a computational and machine learning 'software as a service' platform that analyzes clinical informatics data from patients hospitalized in an inpatient psychiatric facility to predict post-discharge risk of readmission. In addition, the proposed platform consists of an advanced analytics engine that recommends available post-discharge intervention services and community resources to enhance the continuity of care. This platform will leverage on historical electronic health records data and a curated database of available community healthcare and social resources. It will predict readmission risk and optimize patient post-discharge interventions. The I-Corps program will allow the team to understand the customer workflow and potential for product-market fit.

Institution.Name: The University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT HOUSTON, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Texas Health Science Center Houston

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) project was to explore a commercialization opportunity for a computational and machine learning 'software as a service' platform that analyzes clinical informatics data from patients hospitalized in an inpatient psychiatric facility to predict post-discharge risk of readmission. We examined several value proposition hypothesis using the lean business canvas model approach as directed by the I-Corps course instructors and other materials. A major component of this project was to perform extensive customer discovery interviews, validate or invalidate value propositon hypotheses and identify a solution that satisfies needs for specific customer segments (e.g. physicians, psychiatrits, case managers, nurses and social workers). It was expected that invalidated hypotheses would lead to changes or "pivots" in either value propositions or target customers. 

Subsequently, over 500 customer discovery interviews were performed nationwide. We explored other sections of the business model canvas (e.g. channels, customer relationships, cost structure, reveneus etc) and arrived at a validated value proposition to develop a software that assists case managers, social workers and case workers to efficiently access heath related community resources.  We have since developed a minimum viable product (MVP) and the ensuing technology licensed to a local company for potential commercialization.  


Last Modified: 10/29/2018
Modified by: Benson Irungu

A major component of this project was to perform extensive customer discovery interviews, validate or invalidate value propositon hypotheses and identify a solution that satisfies needs for specific customer segments (e.g. physicians, psychiatrits, case managers, nurses and social workers). It was expected that invalidated hypotheses would lead to changes or "pivots" in either value propositions or target customers. We explored other sections of the business model canvas (e.g. channels, customer relationships, cost structure, reveneus etc) and arrived at a validated value proposition to develop a software that assists case managers, social workers and case workers to efficiently access heath related community resources.
